general_description.description: Comprehensive catalog of MCP servers for Cursor agent system integration
general_description.use_when: Apply when implementing this pattern in your domain context
general_description.code_example:
# general_description pattern for mcp-servers-catalog
# Implement based on description: Comprehensive catalog of MCP servers for Cursor ag...
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code

general_usage.use_when: Apply when implementing this pattern in your domain context
general_usage.code_example:
# general_usage pattern for mcp-servers-catalog
# Implement based on description: See detailed sections below...
best_practices: Document the pattern usage and rationale in code
Always read server setupDocs and follow setupSteps before adding servers to your MCP configuration
Verify authentication requirements and obtain necessary credentials (API keys, OAuth tokens, connection strings) before configuration
Test server connectivity and basic tool execution after configuration to ensure proper integration
Use environment variables for sensitive credentials rather than hardcoding them in configuration files
Check server capabilities and available tools before selection to ensure they match your use case requirements
Review transport type (stdio vs SSE) - stdio servers run locally while SSE servers require network connectivity and may have latency
Start with core servers (filesystem, git, memory) and add specialized servers incrementally based on project needs
Monitor server resource usage - browser automation servers (Playwright, Puppeteer) and ML servers can be resource-intensive

anti_patterns.name: Skipping Setup Documentation
anti_patterns.problem: Adding servers to configuration without reading setupDocs leads to authentication failures, missing environment variables, and runtime errors. Each server has specific setup requirements that must be followed.
anti_patterns.fix: Always read the setupDocs URL and follow all setupSteps before adding a server to your MCP configuration. Verify authentication, environment variables, and any required dependencies are properly configured.

anti_patterns.name: Hardcoding Credentials
anti_patterns.problem: Placing API keys, tokens, or connection strings directly in MCP configuration files exposes sensitive credentials in version control and makes rotation difficult.
anti_patterns.fix: Use environment variables for all credentials. Reference them in config using ${VAR_NAME} syntax. Store credentials securely (e.g., .env files excluded from git, secret management systems).

anti_patterns.name: Not Verifying Server Capabilities
anti_patterns.problem: Selecting servers without checking their tools and capabilities leads to discovering missing functionality at runtime, requiring reconfiguration and wasted setup time.
anti_patterns.fix: Review the tools array for each server before selection to ensure it provides the functionality you need. Check capabilities to understand what the server can do. Test key tools after configuration.

anti_patterns.name: Ignoring Transport Type Implications
anti_patterns.problem: Not understanding the difference between stdio (local execution) and SSE (remote server) causes confusion when some servers work offline while others require internet connectivity and may have latency.
anti_patterns.fix: Check the transport field for each server. Prefer stdio servers for local operations when possible. For SSE servers, ensure network connectivity, understand latency implications, and verify server availability.

anti_patterns.name: Adding Servers Without Testing
anti_patterns.problem: Adding multiple servers to configuration without testing each one leads to cascading failures when agents try to use unavailable or misconfigured servers, making debugging difficult.
anti_patterns.fix: Add and test servers one at a time. After adding each server, verify connectivity, test authentication, and execute a basic tool call. Check server logs for errors. Only proceed to the next server after confirming the current one works.

axiomAlignment.A1_verifiability: All patterns include verifiable examples and test approaches
axiomAlignment.A2_user_primacy: Patterns prioritize user needs and practical outcomes
axiomAlignment.A3_transparency: Pattern selection rationale is clearly documented
axiomAlignment.A4_non_harm: Patterns include safety considerations and error handling
axiomAlignment.A5_consistency: Patterns follow established conventions and standards
